description: From Chaucer’s character Pandare (in Troilus and Criseyde), from Italian Pandaro (found in Boccaccio), from Latin Pandarus, from Ancient Greek Πάνδαρος (Pándaros). (See also Shakespeare’s Troilus and Cressida.)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A person who furthers the illicit love affairs of others; a pimp or procurer, especially when male.

verbs.description: pandar (third-person singular simple present pandars, present participle pandaring, simple past and past participle pandared)

entries.meaning: To pander (assist in the gratification of).
examples: That degenerate aſſembly even pandared to the libidinous epicuriſm of this many-wived tyrant; and outraged, at his command, the rights of decorum, of juſtice, and of nature.
